description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Organisationen The Adventist Development Relief Agency (ADRA) har ansökt till Sida om finansiering på 68 miljoner kronor för att genomföra programmet Somalia WASH Service Delivery Improvement Program (SOWASDIP)" i Somalia under perioden 2019-2023. Detta inkluderar 8 000 000 kronor som Sida har tilldelat för att stödja arbetet i Somalia NGO Consortium under samma period.
Programmet syftar till att förbättra hälso- och miljöförhållandena för en fortsatt tillgång till vatten-, sanitets- och hygienbaserade tjänster (WASH). Specifikt kommer programmet att: 1) Stärka de möjliggörande faktorerna och governance-strukturerna för att stödja leverans av lämpliga, rättvisa och prisvärda WASH-tjänster, 2) öka tillgången till hållbart, rättvist och billigt säkert vatten genom välskötta vattenförsörjningssystem på landsbygden, i städer och i utkanter av städer 3) öka tillgången till förbättrade, lämpliga och rättvisa sanitets- och hygientjänster, och 4) Ökad hushållsinkomst som ett resultat förbättrade WASH-tjänster. ADRA kommer att genomföra programmet tillsammans med den somaliska regeringen, det civila samhällets organisationer, den privata sektorn och det somaliska NGO-konsortiet. Programmet kommer geografiskt att riktas sig till utvalda distrikt i South Central, Puntland, Somaliland och staterna Galmudug, South West och Jubbaland. Primära målgrupper kommer att vara kvinnor och flickor från fattiga hushåll som bor i städer, i utkanten av städer och på landsbygden, inklusive de nomadiska befolkningarna och internflyktingar.
Programmets totala budget uppgår till 68 miljoner kronor med Sida som enda finansiär. Cirka 15 miljoner kronor av programbudgeten kommer att vidarebefordras från ADRA till genomförande av civila samhällsorganisationer och 8 miljoner kronor till NGO-konsortiet.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The Adventist Development Relief Agency (ADRA) has applied to Sida for funding of 68 million SEK to carry out the 'Somalia WASH Service Delivery Improvement Programme (SOWASDIP)' in Somalia during the period 2019-2023. This includes SEK 8 000 000 that Sida has allocated to support the work of the Somalia NGO Consortium during the same period.
The intervention aims at improving health and environmental conditions as a result of sustained access to water, sanitation and hygiene promotion (WASH) services. Specifically, the intervention will 1) Strengthen the enabling environment and governance structures to support the delivery of appropriate, equitable and affordable WASH services, 2) increase access to sustained, equitable and affordable safe water through well managed water supply systems in rural, peri-urban and urban settlements, 3) increase access to improved, adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene services, and 4) Increased household income as a result improved WASH services . ADRA will implement the intervention together with the Somali governments, Civil Society Organizations, the private sector, and the Somalia NGO consortium. The intervention will geographically target select districts in South Central, Puntland, Somaliland and the states (Galmudug, South West, and Jubbaland). Primary target beneficiaries will be women and girls from poor households living in urban, peri-urban and rural areas including the nomadic populations and Internally Displaced Persons.
The intervention’s total budget is 68 million SEK which will be totally funded by Sida. Approximately 17 million SEK of the intervention budget will be forwarded from ADRA to implementing civil society organizations and 8 MSEK to the NGO consortium.

Program Goal: Improved health and environmental conditions due to sustained access to WASH services contributing to reduced poverty and improved economic status of Somali people. Outcome 1: Strengthened enabling environment and governance structure supporting delivery of appropriate, equitable and affordable WASH services. Outcome 2: Increased access to sustained, reliable, equitable and affordable safe water through well managed water supply systems in rural, peri-urban areas and urban centres Outcome 3: Increased access to improved, adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene services in rural, peri-urban and urban areas Outcome 4: Improved economic performance of local livelihoods reliant on improved access to WASH services Outcome 5: An enabling environment for the efficient and effective delivery of humanitarian and development assistance for all Somali people.

description.narrative:
Result one: Strengthened enabling environment and governance structure supporting delivery of appropriate, equitable, and affordable WASH services
The program supported capacity-building workshops, training and meetings to strengthen the capacities of the government, partners, and stakeholders to deliver the Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) services. These were done by way of community participation, strengthening government enforcement structures, and stakeholder engagement. A total of 499 people (409 male and 90 female) were reached through the various fora, working in partnership with Ministry of Energy and Water Resources (MoEWR) and Federal Member States (FMS). ADRA for example accomplished the following in 2021:
i) Trained 44 people (36 men and 8 women) in Southwest State, Jubaland, and Galmudug states trained on water management and operations after the completions of water infrastructures.
ii) Conducted WASH policy forums and consultative meetings to discuss and review the existing WASH policy led by the MOEWR in Galmudug and southwest states where both states adopted the national WASH policy (draft). ADRA further supported the MoEWRs to conduct 10 sector coordination meetings in Baidao, Dhusamareeb, Kismayo, Beletweyne, Garowe and Hargeisa. Through these a total of 333 people (304 male; 29 female) were reached.
iii) Conducted consultative workshops on the WASH cluster partners which reached 92 people (68 male and 24 female). Conducted a 3-days consumer complaint mechanism workshop that brought together 20 people (11 male; 9 female) consumer groups/stakeholders in Baidoa.
Result two: Increased access to sustained, reliable, equitable and affordable safe water through well-managed water supply systems in rural, peri-urban areas and urban centres
To increase access to water, the program rehabilitated existing non/ dysfunctional strategic water points and established new water sources depending on community needs. Through the water supply infrastructures constructed/ rehabilitated the project managed to reach 27,700 beneficiaries (6,925, women, 8,587 girls, 6,648 boys and 5,540 men).
Result three: Increased access to improved, adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene services in rural, peri-urban and urban areas
This result has reached at least 31,489 people (17,427 male; 14,061 female) through various fronts including WASH in Schools (WINS), Community-Led Total Sanitation (CLTS), construction / rehabilitation of latrines in schools and through general sanitation and hygiene promotion where the following were conducted. A total of 19,443 learners (11,085 boys and 8,171 girls) were supported through WINS in the 29 schools in Somaliland and Puntland. Also, 32 teachers & community education committees were trained on WINS. In the 29 schools, some 127 additional learners joined child clubs through the WINS programming. Further, an additional1,000 learners gained water access through pipeline extension and connection to WASH facilities. The beneficiary schools received services such as WINS training, provision of sanitation tools, dignity kits, and formed and trained through child clubs. By 2021, 48 schools out of the 50 targeted for WINS implementation had been identified in partnership with the Ministry of Education (MoE) of these 15 are Puntland, 16 in Somaliland 18 in Galmudug.
The program supported 2,946 additional people (736 women, 914 girls, 707 boys, and 589 men) representing additional 491 households in 35 villages in the districts of Qardho in Puntland, Burco and Ergabo in Somaliland to have access to latrines following the Community Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) triggering. By late 2021, 5 villages (Jidad, Xuddun-reer, Dhaxxan, Shaxda and Cambaar-sare) had attained Open Defecation Free (ODF) certification.
Result four: Improved household income through engagement in provision of WASH services (water supply, sanitation management and promotion of good hygiene practice
On this result, not much was achieved in 2021. Activities here include training youth, establishment of Public Private Partnerships approaches, provision of start- up kits, set of tools for operators, establishment of the disposal sites (landfills), establishment of pilot schemes with local authorities, youth and women, recycle waste for Income Generating Activities, pilot scheme with local authorities for faecal treatment and provision of Grants for recycling (IDP groups, youth groups and women) / waste segregation.
Somalia NGO Consortium
The support to Somali NGO Consortium (SNC) on advocacy lead to an improved understanding of the implications of the current political situation on aid delivery. SNC continued to support humanitarian coordination efforts and facilitated a strong NGO voice in key coordination fora vis à vis the wider humanitarian community implementing programs in Somalia. As of September 2021, 111 NGOs working in Somalia were actively coordinated through the Consortiums diverse platforms. There was also increased awareness on the localization agenda at local and global platforms. Key among the achievements in 2021 was the advocacy on the draft NGO bill 2019 at the Federal level.
Furthermore, the Consortium convened 5 monthly membership coordination meetings for Country Directors level; 25 regional monthly membership coordination meetings (5 in Mogadishu, 5 in Hargeisa, 5 in Garowe, 5 in Kismayo and 5 in Baidoa). SNC paired 3 INGOs with 12 local NGOs for the capacity building based on local NGOs existing major gaps with INGOs conducting a capacity assessment for these organizations. The first phase of the trainings were completed with all trainings conducted via virtual methods and also physically. The SNC conducted feedback sessions to discuss what worked well and what needs to be improved for the upcoming phase
SNC in conjunction with UNRMU (United nations Risk Management Unit) conducted the rolling out of information and dissemination of the Somalia CRM (Collaborative risk framework) to its members. Subsequently, an implementation plan (5years) has been developed and SNC tasked with engaging NGOS to identify their risks, areas of contribution and CRM focal person. SNC is the lead in assisting NGOs.
